titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: Sonnet—to a Sun-Dial.

lg.l: Thou silent Herald of Time’s ceaseless flight
Say—couldst thou speak—what warning voice were thine?
Shade-filled but to mark how others shine—
Dark, sullen witness of resplendent light.
In day’s broad glare, and when the moon-tide bright
Of prosperous Fortune, sheds the ray divine
Thy services attend us, but decline
The clouds of morning, and the glooms of night.
Yet, are thy Counsels, faithful, just and wise:
They bid us grasp the moments as they pass,
Snatch the retrieveless Sun beam as he flies,
Nor lose one Sand of life’s revolving glass.
By deathless deeds to give Eternity to Time.

div.p: The volume begins with Thanksgiving to almighty God, for all the blessings I enjoy, and in a special manner, for the prospect of recovery of my infant Granddaughter Mary-Louisa, the eldest child of my Son John— The alarming symptoms of her disease have abated; and Dr Holbrook, who was here this morning thought it would not be necessary for him to repeat again his visit to prescribe for her— I worked two hours in the garden Nursery; planting a row of Shellbark nuts from my tree in the garden, the nut of which I planted in October 1804— With them I now planted, alternate White and Chesnut Oak Acorns; and in another line, about half as deep, Peach Stones, Stranger berries, Ashpods, wild cherries, Pears whole seeds and Cores— My only plantation last year was a row of Apple-seeds, which had come up confusedly amidst the weeds when I arrived here early last June. I plucked up one of them by mistake for a weed and then put it into the ground again on the other side of the alley, on the side of a Cornhill. Some days after S. Farrar took up others of the trees which had come up in a cluster, and replaced them at distances of about 6. inches from each other— There were sixteen in all— I mark their growth in the Season— Of three remaining where the seed was planted, one is twelve, one ten, and one eight inches high. Of those transplanted none are more than three inches high some not more than two— Only two of the whole number have died—scorched by the Sun. I expect that none but perhaps the three tallest will survive the Winter; and I take the growth of the tallest, as the average growth of an apple-tree from the seed, it its first Summer, one foot— Mr T. Loring and Mrs Whittemore from Hingham paid us a visit this afternoon—and I rode with my wife to Weymouth, to the Milleners— Gathered a few white Oak Acorns, as we returned
2. IV:15. Saturday— Boston—dined with I. P. Davis— Quincy.

Our repose of the Night was again disturbed for two hours from Midnight, by the child. My brother was here this Morning— I went with my wife into Boston—called at Charles’s House; whence I went to his office and there found him. Mr Nathaniel Curtis called there; and we had some consultation what to do, in the process of Execution of Mr.
W. N. Boylston’s Will— Mr Curtis sent me a few days since, a Letter from Petty Vaughan; giving notice that Sir Benjamin H. Carew, now refused to sign a renunciation of claim as an heir to Thomas Boylston, which he had promised, but which Petty Vaughan ought never to have asked— We concluded that Petty Vaughan’s motive was to make a pretext for retaining the money which he ought to have remitted; and that when we hear from Messrs. Bates and Baring to whom we sent a power of Attorney, and I as Administrator of Thomas Boylston, another it will be necessary to determine if we can take any effective step to recover the money. I called at Pendleton’s Lithographic shop; paid him a bill for book labels, and enquired the cost of engraving a design including in quarters my fathers devise of the Pine tree, Deer and fish, with the Smith, Boylston and Quincy arms—and the Lion crest. His price was 20 dollars which brought me to a pause for the present— I made some hardware purchases for the fire-place, and dined with Isaac P. Davis—his brother the judge and his Son—B. Gorham. Alexander H. and Edward Everett, Jos. Coolidge junr. formed the company William Sturges came in after dinner— Conversation upon French and European Politics. Mrs Davis not there— Nursing her neighbour Mrs Webster, who is ill— About Sunset I returned to Charles’s House; and he and his wife came out with us to Quincy.
3. IV:30. Sunday.

Heard P. Whitney this morning from John 16.14. He shall glorify me: for he shall receive of mine, and shall shew it unto you; and in the afternoon from Matthew 19.17. [“]If thou wilt enter into life, keep the Commandments.” After the usual Morning service the communion was administered— Mr Whitney gave notice of the change to the winter time of Meeting—half past ten the morning. 1/4 before 2 afternoon. I rode with Charles to the Mount Wollaston farm—to shew him where I propose to set out my Orchard— Alpheus Spear was gone to Boston. We found some white Walnuts, but no Acorns— Mr and Mrs John Greenleaf called to see us in the Evening. Charles went to my brother’s. I wrote by a furnace fire, and went to bed chill’d with cold, and suffering with the Lumbago— Finished reading Cicero de Officiis—perhaps the most excellent of his works. perhaps the last of the works of his old age, and that which exhibits him in the most venerable and affecting aspect— At the last stage of life, driven from the Senate and the Forum so long the Scenes of his glory; silenced by the Triumph of Caesar over the Liberties of his Country, and at the eve of perishing a martyr to the cause of those Liberties seemingly for a moment restored, he avails himself of the last hours allowed him, of existence to compose and address to his Son, just arriving at the age of manhood, and pursuing his studies at Athens a general Treatise of morals, teaching him all the duties of human life— This system of ethics is imperfect, because not illuminated with the light of the gospel— But it is the most perfect then known— It connects itself with the questions concerning the boundaries of good and evil—and supposes that the determination of human action depends upon the will— All the Greek Philosophers founded their principles of Morals, upon the assumption that the rule of human conduct was a subject of deliberation: That man was formed to seek his own happiness, and
to adapt his actions to the attainment of the greatest possible good: and Since all their discussions what was the Supreme Good; and their diverse conclusions, one fixing it in pleasure; one in virtue; and a third in living according to Nature— There was no system emanating from a Superior Power, in the form of command— The Epicurean theory, which made pleasure the Supreme Good, and which though admitting Gods, pro forma, pronounced them indifferent to all human Affairs, had under this state of things an immense advantage over all others. It was irresistibly fascinating, and buried all morals in the grave of sensuality— In every part of his philosophical works Cicero treats it with uncompromising severity—but it was nevertheless the prevailing philosophy at Rome— Hence also the decisive superiority of the Christian morality, over those of the Greek Philosophers— The duties of the Christian are prescribed to him by his maker— He has no preliminary question to settle, what is the Supreme good. Obedience to God, and good will to his fellow creatures compose all his obligations. And as these are enjoined upon him as commands, they have the sanction of a special revelation from Heaven— The age of Cicero preceded by so short a time the birth of Christ, that a comparison of his work with the Gospels, is curious to shew how far unaided human reason could advance in the school of morals—and where and to what ends a Revelation was necessary.
4. V:45. Monday.

I was chilled last Evening, by the ride to Mount Wollaston farm, and had in consequence of it a painful Night— Charles and his wife returned to Boston, and we are left to our resources— I planted 8 Gay Pear-seeds in Book-Box N. 3. and a Row of Office (Woodhouse) Apple seeds in the line of the Cornhill Apple-seedling— Also White Walnuts and Shellbarks, White Oak Acorns, Horse Chesnuts, Peach Stones, ash pods, Stranger berries, Wild Cherries and Pears— I cut off a twig of Button wood, and stuck it into the ground at the Southeast corner of the Cornhill patch— After dinner I walked to the Druid plain, and gathered perhaps two quarts of white Oak, and chesnut Oak Acorns— The ripeness of the first is already decaying: the second are now falling and ready to fall from their eyes— I find no others. This Evening I read 15 Sections of the Cato Major, de Senectute—a Treatise which has been familiar to me from my youth; and which in 1788 I partly translated. Addressed to Athens— The main speaker is Cato the elder, conversing with Scipio and Laelius, and discoursing to them upon Old Age.
5. V. Tuesday.

Mr Humphreys brought me the plan of the Penn’s Valley farm divided into the four lots of which it was composed— The deficiency of 8 Acres in the purchase from the Vesey’s, set down in the Deeds for 46 Acres more or less, and which turns out to be only 38— We are to commence the Mount Wollaston survey next Monday if the weather should be fair— Mills the Painter was here, with a small bill, and I desired him to make an estimate, and let me know the cost of new painting the whole outside of my house, and the garden fence. Mr Curtis the Treasurer of the Congregational Society paid me a year’s interest due the first of this Month, upon notes to me, and to the Executors of my father’s Will— He spoke with some circumlocution of the nominations of me in the newspapers, to represent the Plymouth-District in the next Congress, and asked me if I would— I said it was
first to be seen, whether the People of the District would invite me to represent them— I should not ask for their votes; and know nothing of their dispositions, except from what had appeared in the Newspapers. I wished them to act their pleasure. Whether I could represent them if they should elect me, might depend upon Circumstances, but if I should find that I could not, I would give them notice in Season to enable them to fix their choice upon another man, before the Meeting of the Congress. I planted a row of Gay Pear seeds—with Shellbarks, White Oak Acorns, Horse Chesnuts, Peach Stones and scattered wild Cherries— The Ninth and last Cornhill row. Besides my general experimental attempts to raise trees from the seed, I wish to ascertain, what seed will vegetate, and how far the fruit will be the same as that of the planted seed— I have therefore now taken much pains to mark with stakes and upon Stones the particular Seeds in each of the rows, so as to distinguish the various kinds of Oaks, Walnuts, Apples and Pears— Also whether planting the whole fruit, or the naked seed will be most successful— After dinner I walked to the Mount Wollaston farm; through Mr. D. Greenleaf’s ground in search of Black Oak Acorns, of which I found none— On one tree with the leaf of the Black-Oak I found four acorns ripening; resembling those of the Pin Oak—on the Northwest side of Mount Wollaston, upon the bleakest aspect are the stumps of two very large trees— I planted two Cap white Oak Acorns there, and scattered with them several Wild Cherries— Alpheus Spear walked round the beach with me to the division line against Mr Daniel Greenleaf— I finished the Dialogue de Senectute, and read 7 Sections of the Laelius, de Amicitia— The Argument of Cato in behalf of Old Age is eloquent; but upon reperusing it as an old man I find it less satisfactory than it was when I read it at the age of twenty-one— Cato enumerates four causes for wretchedness in old age— First that it disqualifies for active business; secondly that it brings infirmities upon the body thirdly that it impairs all the pleasure; and fourthly that it is so near to Death— He answers to each of those objections successively; but the difficulty is stronger to the Active energies of men than the Solution— In the 7th. Section he repeats the line from Cecilius Serit arbores quae alteri Seculo prosint which he had already quoted in the Books de Finibus.
6. III.45. Wednesday.

I rose between three and four with an anxious determination to go through some of my business long deferred—and was disappointed— The reading was accomplished before breakfast and I resumed for half an hour the assortment of my fathers papers— But in retirement as when overwhelmed with the duties of public service; from breakfast time for the remnant of the day I have no command of time—no—not for a Quarter of an hour— My two hours of exercise were occupied in the Nursery where I continued the trench already commenced from the central Apple-tree towards the fence; and planted white Oak Acorns in the trench leading to that Tree; with several Horse-Chesnuts— Planted also one whole Dwarf Apple and the Seeds of another; both of which I staked, and surrounded with Stones. Measured by pacing the length of the Garden; near about 200 feet— I had scarcely returned to the House when President Quincy called and spent an hour with me. He enquired respecting the papers to be prepared for the Probate Office in the Execution of the my father’s Will, and I had them not ready— I told him I would have them for Session of Probate Court here next Month— While he was here a man who said his name was Sweetser, and that he belonged to Reading, and out of mere curiosity importuned
me with a number of not very pertinent enquiries, much to the amusement of Mr Quincy. Mr William Lee came in soon after and dined with us— He is to be married next week to the widow of Mr John M’lean of Boston of the Amory family— Lee is sixty years of age, with a family of four grown up children; one of his daughters being married to Baron Maltitz, some time Secretary of Russian Legation here; and now a Counsellor of the same Legation at Berlin— Lee was many years Second Auditor of the Treasury, and was removed by General Jackson at the commencement of his Administration— Mrs M’lean at least fifty-five; and was left by her former husband in great affluence, without children— It is on her part a love match; for Lee has no property and abundance of debts. This project has been at least two years fermenting; for her family connections numerous and respectable are all greatly averse to the connection— About this time last year they succeeded in breaking it off, but it is now on the point of consummation. He very earnestly invited me to the wedding; and told me the substance of the marriage contract; which is very liberal on the part of the Lady— My brother’s daughter Elizabeth also dined with us, and rode to Milton with us after dinner. John’s wife and two children, had rode in the Carriage before dinner— The first time Mary had been since her confinement— From the Railway, I walked home, over the hills back of Mrs Baxter’s—but I found no acorns there.
7. III.45 Thursday.

My brother was here this Morning; while digging in my Nursery, a man named Levi Joseph came to borrow money upon a mortgage of real Estate but I had none to lend. Dug a Trench from the central old Apple tree, to a rock like Stone, which I leave for a boundary— I planted 7 Garden Shellbarks in the Drupe between the Thimble berry vine, and the central Apple-tree with white Oak Acorns, Horse Chesnuts, wild Cherries, office Apple seeds and 3. Pear Cores. There came in extreme agitation a man named F. A. Strale, who implored of me aid to extricate him from ruin, caused as he said by his own guilt and folly— He is a native of Sweden; served Some time as a soldier in our army,—changed his profession, and commenced a Calvinist preacher.— He settled at Allentown in Pennsylvania, and has been travelling to collect subscriptions to build a Church there— He had collected accordingly a considerable sum; but being at New-York, was led into temptation by an opportunity to purchase Lottery tickets— He had a large bundle of them which he held up before me, and with a look of desperation uttered a hearty curse upon them— Blinded by the delusion of hope, to make his fortune by the chances of the wheel, he gave for Lottery Tickets the money that he had received for building the Church, and now—he had sowed the wind, and reaped the whirlwind— He had applied to Mr. Wisner, the Minister at Boston, without success, and was going to a Clergymen in this neighbourhood, to solicit relief but found he was at the point of death, so that it was impossible to speak to him on this subject— As he was passing by my house the thought had occurred to him that from consideration of mere humanity, I might be willing to step forward and extricate him the jaws of Ruin— He had an excellent wife, and two children who must be involved in it with him— He had a small property, sufficient to cover his delinquency, but was in Sweden in the hand of his brother; and if this transaction should become known his utter ruin would be inevitable, as it would blast his character, and disqualify him even for his profession as a preacher of the
Gospel— His appearance was sincere and candid, and his distress very affecting— I told him I regretted it was not in my power to relieve him; and advised him not to give way to discouragement— To restore by drawing his property from Sweden, the funds which he had indiscreetly applied to other purposes than those for which he had obtained them, and to redeem the weakness of the past by firmness and fortitude at present. He seemed to be soothed by these observations, and left me with thanks for my kindness, and with a request that I would not divulge his communication to one, which I readily promised— I rode after dinner with my wife, and Elizabeth C Adams who we took up at her father’s, to Weymouth. Returning, I walked from the top of Penn’s Hill, home— The Acorns both of the White and of the Rock Chesnut Oak, are already gone.— They must be gathered the last week of September— I finished the Laelius de Amicitia, and read the six Paradoxes, addressed to Marcus Brutus—
8. IV:15. Friday. Sun rose 6.21.— Frost— Fahrenheit 32. after Sunrise.

Joseph Hardwick called this morning, and paid me a half-year’s Rent of the House where he lives.— In the Nursery I continued digging the Trench from the central Apple-tree to the central rock— Part planted it with Garden Shellbarks in drupe, white Oak Acorns, Althea, and wild grape seeds, Stranger berries, Peach-stones, and wild Cherries— My brother and his daughter Elizabeth dined with us— Deacon Spear called on me after dinner— I agreed with him to make sale at Auction of the two lots of Woodland belonging to my fathers Estate which remain yet unsold—the Sale to be on Wednesday the 27th. of this Month at 3 in the afternoon. I determined also to lease on the same day at 10 in the Morning, for terms from one to five years, to accommodate different purchasers, the two dwelling-houses at the foot of Penn’s Hill, and the farm adjoining them in separate lots as they are divided by Wall fences. I wrote a notice for the Executor’s Sale to be posted up by the Deacon at proper places— About the Arrangements for the Leases I am to see him again— John’s wife rode out yesterday, the first time since her confinement, and again this morning. Elizabeth rode this afternoon with my wife— I walked over the Hills; gathered a few Stranger berries, still ripening and gleaned a a few Trask Shellbarks remaining on one of the Trees— Spent an hour of the Evening at Mr Thomas Greenleaf’s— Read this morning a part of the Fragments appended to the various Editions of Cicero’s Works, including among them the beautiful Somnium Scipionis, from the lost though in part recently recovered Books de Republica—
9. IV:15. Saturday.— Boston— Charlestown.

Visited the Nursery and continued the plantation from the central old Apple tree towards the central rock— The Garden Shell-barks, planted in the drupe on green shell, are the nuts for which I have chiefly dug this Trench; and my purpose is to raiseShellbark Trees to range along this Western Wall, and to live and grow where they shall come up; without transplantation— The other acorns and seeds I throw in; merely to give them the chance of coming up, and to observe the growth of such as may vegetate— They are white Oak Acorns, Horse-Chesnuts—Old Althea Seeds, Stranger berries, wild Cherries, Peach Stones and Whole Pears— Went to Boston with my wife. To Charles’s House where I left my wife— To his Office— A. H. Everett called there with his wife’s brother Peabody. Charles took 84 dollars and deposited them in the U.S. Branch Bank to the credit of the Executors of my father: he also purchased at 3 per Cent advance seven Shares of the Boylston
Fire and Marine Insurance Company, for Thomas B. Adams junr— Just as we arrived in Boston it began to rain, and continued raining all the remainder of the day— I dined with Charles at Edward Everett’s in Charlestown— Genl. S. Van Rensselaer the Patroon, J. S. Johnston the Senator from Louisiana, with his Son, A. H. Everett, and Mr Peabody, R. Gorham, Commodore Morris, Mr Hale, a Mr Schroeder of Baltimore and his Son were the company— Mrs Everett the only Lady— Not much conversation— In the Evening I returned with Charles to his house in Boston, where we are to pass the Night.
10. IV:15. Sunday.

From my rising hour till after Sunrise I passed reading and writing in Charles’s Study— After breakfast we returned to Quincy but did not reach home till it was too late to attend the morning service at Meeting— I went in the afternoon and heard Mr Lamson of Dedham, from Matthew 7.13. Enter ye in at the strait gate— In the evening I answered a letter from Charles Miner, Editor of a Newspaper at West Chester, Pennsylvania, called the village Record, and during the four years of the last Administration a member of the House of Representatives in Congress— A single Night passed in Boston, especially following a dinner of Company, discomposes the arrangements of my time, and the order of my occupations. The reading of Cicero yesterday and this morning was wholly suspended. The fragments, excepting the Somnium Scipionis, and the Timaeus are all so short, and so separated from the discourses whence they are quoted that their chief effect is to sharpen regret at the large portion of Cicero’s works which are lost.— Of the two Treatises de Senectute, and de Amicitia, the latter is most practically useful though the former is perhaps the most philosophical. There are consolations and comforts in Old Age— But we cannot listen with conviction to arguments that its infirmities are not evils— As to Friendship there are few examples of it in antiquity to be compared with that of the second Scipio Africanus and Laelius, who is the chief Speaker in the Dialogue of Cicero— It is supposed to have happened a few days after the death of Scipio, when the two Sons in Law of Laelius were with him. Quintus Mucius Scaevola the Augur, and Caius Fannius. They take the occasion, after remarking the ardent friendship of Lelius for Scipio, to inquire how he was affected by his death, and then, his Sentiments upon Friendship in general, which he gives.— Cicero says that when he assumed the toga of manhood by the advice of his father, he very much frequented this Augur Mucius Scevola; and after his death the Pontiff Scaevola— That Mucius very often entertained him with narratives of the sayings in former times of his father in Law Laelius and particularly that one day, sitting in his hemicycle, on the occasion of a rupture followed by the most inveterate hostility between Publius Sulpicius and Quintus Pompeius who until then, had been in the closest intimacy of friendship with each other, he had given a very particular account of the discourse upon Friendship, held so long before by Laelius, to his two Sons in law— And this discourse now reduced to writing by Cicero is the Treatise de Amicitia. He reminds Atticus that he had often urged him to write upon Friendship, and mentions his own partiality for the theme—observes the peculiar propriety of selecting Laelius to lay down the Laws of Friendship, as Cato had been the most appropriate person to comment upon old age. He closes the introductory Address with an elegant and affectionate reference to the friendship between Atticus and himself, and asks his friend to discard him for the time from his thoughts, and imagine himself listening to Laelius, and adds that as the whole subject of the Dialogue is Friendship he hopes that Atticus while reading will recognize himself.
11. Monday. IV.

Mr Humphrey the Surveyor came at Eight this Morning. William Spear was also punctually here— I took Salmon Farrar with me, and went down to the House of the Mount Wollaston farm— Both the brothers Alpheus and Lemuel Spear were gone to Brighton, but George Spear another brother went with us and assisted in carrying the Chains. We began at the Southwest Corner upon the North side of the Road, and followed the fence to its end in Quincy’s Creek, just below Mr Daniel Greenleaf’s wharves— Thence we followed the course of the creek to its mouth, and then the windings of the bay, till we passed by Half-Moon, and came to the line of separation, of a parcel said to be six or seven Acres belonging to a family by the name of Crane; after which, about two O’Clock we sat down upon the upland heath, and dined from our basket— We then resumed the Survey, till we came to the border of Rock-Island, which is entirely separate from the rest of the farm— We closed the day by going round it, and left the ground at dusk of Evening— It was quite dark when I got home. I had a severe headache, and was more unwell than I have been at any time this year— Mr Gourgas, and my brothers daughter Elizabeth were here half an hour— I retired before nine O’Clock to bed.
12. IV. Tuesday.

I rose this morning as usual at four, after a good Night’s rest and much refreshed. I had finished yesterday the fragments of Cicero’s Philosophical works, closing with the translation of Plato’s unintelligible Timaeus— This morning I began the books de Republica, recently recovered though in a very imperfect state by Angelo May, and published at Rome in 1822— There is internal evidence of its authenticity and probably one fourth part of the work—enough at least to make the mouth water for the rest— It begins by stating that the first 34 pages of the manuscript are missing— It opens in the midst of a discussion by Cicero, upon the Question whether a wise man ought to take part in the Administration of public Affairs—of which he maintains the affirmative. He then undertakes to set forth a discourse of the second Scipio Africanus, which he says was related to him, and to Brutus, then a youth, by Publius Rutilius Rufus at Smyrna. The occasion is said to have been during the Feriae Latinae, Tuditanus and Aquilius being Consuls, (year of Rome 625.[)] about 80 years before the composition of the work. Scipio passes the festival days at his Gardens where he is visited by his familiar friends— First appears his Sister’s Son, Quintus Tubero— Then Lucius Furius Philus and Publius Rutilius and finally Laelius, with Spurius Mummius, Caius Fannius and Quintus Scaevola; and last of all Marcus Manilius— The conversation is commenced by Tubero who enquires of Scipio what he thinks of the phenomenon said to have been recently observed, of a double Sun— Scipio transfers the question to Philus, between whom and Laelius some desultory dialogue occurs— The other personages take part in it—till after much variety of observation, Laelius calls upon Scipio, to speak of higher topics, and instead of attempting to account for two Suns—to explain, how in one Republic there have come to be two Senates and two Peoples, as there seemed to be by the dissensions consequent upon the tribunate and death of Tiberius Gracchus— The proper subject of the work is thus introduced, and at the request of Laelius, seconded by the other interlocutors, Scipio discourses upon Forms of Government and Republics. This introduction occupies more than half of the first Book; and more than half of it is yet unrecovered. It amused and entertained me till Mr. Humphrey called to finish the survey of Mount Wollaston farm— We resumed it
where we had finished yesterday and Alpheus Spear was with us this day. We came round upon the borders of the broad Meadows, and after dining between two and three O’Clock under an Oak tree, finished the survey about five, and which I immediately came home; not much fatigued, and quite well— Degrand came, on a visit from Boston, and spent an hour with us; and I went to a wedding party at the widow Baxter’s— Her daughter had just before been married by Mr. Whitney to Mr Hallett of Boston— A numerous Company; from Boston, Milton and Quincy; few of whom were known to me— Came home before nine.
13. IV:30. Wednesday.

Mr Richardson and Mr Lincoln called upon me this morning and informed me of the proceedings of the Republican Convention yesterday, at Halifax— Two Conventions had been called in the Newspapers; both to meet at Halifax; to fix upon a Candidate to represent the District of Plymouth in the 22d. Congress— One Call was to the Republicans, and the other was to the National Republicans— The first met yesterday, and the second is to meet this day.— The Republicans I suppose, are those who in the former party divisions declined acting with the federalists— Their meeting was first appointed for to-morrow, but the day was then altered to yesterday—probably for the purpose of preceding the Meeting of this day— Mr Richardson observed that Mr Lincoln had been present at the Meeting and would inform me of their proceedings. Mr Lincoln said, that eleven towns had been represented in the Convention— The usual practice had been for the Republicans in each town, to send to the Convention as many members as the Town was authorised to send the Legislature of the State— And the agreement was that all the members should support the person selected by the majority— But yesterday the number of volunteer intruders exceeded that of the regular delegations from the Towns.— These intruders were Jackson men; officers of the Customs houses, Post-masters, and Jackson Office-hunters; of whom there were ten from Middleborough—Six from Plymouth; and stragglers wherever they could be found— They first gave notice that they would not be bound by the vote of the Majority; and then moved that the Convention should be dissolved, without making any nomination— To this the delegations from the Towns would not consent; but upon taking the vote for going into a Nomination the vote was 30 for and 32 against it. The Convention then was dissolved, and the delegates from the Towns met separately; chose the same Moderator Seth Sprague—and another Secretary, and then unanimously voted to support John Quincy Adams, to represent the District in the 22d. Congress— The other party had also a separate meeting; and nominated Mr Turner of Scituate—not a Jackson man; but merely to divide the vote, and in the hope that the AntiMasons, who are to meet next week will vote also for Turner— Mr Richardson, and Mr Lincoln said they had thought proper to give me this information, to guard against any misrepresentation that might be made to me of the transaction. I thanked them for their kind attention and said that I should acquiesce entirely in the course which might be taken by the People of the District— And so I am launched again upon the faithless Wave of Politics— I continued planting in the Nursery— Finished the trench from the central Apple tree to the central Rock—deposited Garden Shellbarks in the drupe—Chesnut Acorns—Horse-Chesnuts and scattered wild Cherries— Dug a trench also on the West side of the Alley—from centre towards the Gate— Planted in two rows Trask Shellbarks in the drupe; Chesnut and White Oak Acorns.— Horse Chesnuts, Apple Seeds—Pear Cores, scattered wild Cherries and Ash pods— Mrs Adams went to Weymouth before dinner— Soon after noon it began to rain; and there was a South-East Storm all the Evening— I read in Miller’s Gardener’s Dictionary the directions for the planting of Acorns.
14. III.45. Thursday— Sun rose 6:30.

My brother was here this Morning and his wife. My wife went to Boston, to spend a few days, with our Son and daughter there. She took Mrs Pitts with her; and Mrs Nowlan who returned here however this Evening. In my Nursery I continued the Trench West of the Alley towards the gate. Planted M. W. White Walnuts in the drupe—Market Chesnuts, White and Chesnut Oak Acorns—Apple seeds 1. Pear—2. Peach Stones—1. Plum Stone—scattered wild Cherries and Stranger berries in two rows 3. and 5 inches deep— My Shell bark tree is fallen into the sere and yellow leaf— The leaves of my young Red Oak tree have turned crimson. The Chesnut Oaks pale yellow— English Oaks yet retain their green; as do most of the peaches plums and Apples— The Horse Chesnut and Elm leaves are faded and falling— Elizabeth C. Adams dined with me and spent the day with Mary— Mr Gourgas came in the Evening and took her home. After dinned I walked over the Trask Hill and to the Druid Plains—gathered a small number of fully ripened stranger berries, ripening pignuts, and about a quart of White and Chestnut Oak Acorns— The latter are fully ripe on the Old Trees and are falling— They do not sprout, as do almost all the White Oak Acorns— Miller says that all Acorns sprout or not in a very little time. That it is exceedingly difficult to keep them, and that they should be planted as soon as ripe—in October— All which is exactly true— The same of Chesnuts— Returning home I stopp’d at Deacon Josiah Adams’s; and asked him to go with me some day, and shew me the bounds of the old Babcock lot, forming a part of the Penn’s Valley farm— He promised to go with me next Tuesday afternoon— My brother sent me a printed hand-bill headed Republican Nomination, announcing that a Convention of Republican Citizens from various towns in Plymouth Congressional District, it was unanimously resolved that John Quincy Adams should be recommended to the Election of Plymouth Congressional District, to represent them in the 22d. Congress—and in the Evening I received a letter from I. L. Hedge as Secretary of the Convention of National Republicans, held yesterday, informing me that they also had selected me as their Candidate, and expressing the wish that I would accept the nomination— I continue to read the late discovered fragments of the Books de Republica, which are tantalizing, by the constant recurrence of desiderated pages.
15. IV. Friday.

Dr Holbrook was here this morning, to visit my son John’s infant daughter, whom he vaccinated last Monday. The arm has taken the virus. There was a warm rain the former part of this day— My brother dined with me, and his daughter Elizabeth came to stay with Mary till next Monday— I had two glass Quart Tumblers filled with Earth, and pressed down a circle of sprouting white Oak Acorns, round the sides of each of them; to see if the tap root will continue shooting, and if it will appear through the glass as happens with Orange-seeds. Almost every one of the white Oak Acorns, that I have gathered in sprouting in my chamber, and neither sand nor loose earth will save them— I fear I shall in spite of every precaution lose them all— In the Nursery I dug a cross Trench at the Stony-barren Centre; and planted a row of Trask white Walnuts in the drupe. With Chesnuts, white and Chesnut Oak Acorns, Apple-seeds, Stranger berries and scattered wild Cherries— Staked only the white Walnuts. The more time and toil I spend upon this Nursery, the more it takes possession of me— I am particularly desirous of planting separately the three kinds of the Hickory—The Shellbark—the white walnut and the pignut; to ascertain if each of them will invariably produce its kind. I propose making as far as possible the same
experiment upon as many kinds of Oak as I can procure, and also upon the fruit trees. Had the circumstances of my life permitted me to commence these experiments forty years ago, and to have pursed them systematically, I should now have possessed a mass of useful information, for which I must grope in the dark, and this farm would have been covered with excellent fruit— But I really commenced my plantations in 1826. and in the narrow compass of my Summer garden cellar— At Washington I pursued it in 1827. and raised some Apple and Orange trees in seeds from Pots; which gave me some experience— The Apple trees were transplanted into the Garden of the President’s House— In September 1827. I fenced off my Nursery here; and began my plantations in it— Not one in twenty of them has succeeded; and I know but partially the causes of their failure— In 1828. I was suddenly called from hence very early in September; by the illness of my wife— I made a large and various collection of Acorns, at Washington, to be planted here, as some of them were; but most of them were lost— The Spring, Summer and Autumn of 1829. were times of trial, calamity and distress— The Nursery was almost entirely neglected— The passion all but extinguished— In the Summer and Autumn of this year it has revived— I have passed nearly two hours of every fair day in the Nursery— Have dug, and manured and planted with my own hands, in the hope of having the next Spring and Summer a thick and various crop of fruit and forest trees to observe and preserve so far as may be found practicable— Nineteen twentieths of them I have no doubt will again perish; but if I can save and raise even one in a hundred of them, my labour will not be lost— Confined to the house this afternoon by weather, I answered several Letters.
16. IV:45. Saturday.

Mr Thomas Greenleaf’s two daughters visited my Son John’s wife this morning— In the Nursery; continued the Trench West of the Alley towards the gate— Planted 12 Nuts of the Juglans glabra vel porcina—the round thin shelled light pignut— Of this tree itself there are several varieties; the nuts of some of them being sweet—but those of which I have planted are bitter and astringent like most of our acorns— With them I planted in two Rows, Chesnuts, sprouted white Oak Acorns—2. Greenleaf Black Oak Acorns; one of them fronting my young red Oak. Stranger berries, Office Apple-seeds; Pear Cores and seeds.— Opened a 3d. short cross Trench West of the Alley, at the Stony-barren—found a gravelly soil, and took out several large Stones— Planted one whole Sickel Pear in Book-box N. 2. with a Stake— I much distrust the success of planting whole Apples and Pears, but hope this year to ascertain its expediency. Consulting Miller’s Abridgment of the Gardener’s Dictionary, fifth Edition, London—1763. I find under the Article of Ploughing, in the midst of advice to plow deep, he says “but it must be understood only of such land, as the staple is deep enough to admit of this, for if the soil is shallow, and either gravel, chalk or stone lie beneath it will be very imprudent to turn up either of those—therefore the depth of the furrows in such lands, must be determined by the staple of the land— By the word Staple must be understood all that depth of Soil next the Surface which is proper for the growth of vegetables[”]— Now this very imprudence is what I am this day committing— That is turning up the gravel in the Stony-barren part of my Nursery, and taking out Stones to the depth of perhaps a foot and a half from the Surface; and here I have planted and intend to plant Nuts, Acorns and Seeds, first filling the spaces vacated by the Stones and gravel, with black mould from the Garden— Whether six or eight inches deep of the staple, will give a hold for the root to penetrate deeper is the problem to be solved— I have warning enough that the plants have no root in stony ground; and that the Sun will burn them up.
After dinner I rode with Elizabeth C. Adams over to Roxbury, and paid a visit to Genl Dearborn. Some Conversation with him upon the Proclamation of the President, declaring our Navigation Laws all repealed; upon the promise of the British Government to open their West India Ports. Discourse upon Trees— The General gave me some seeds of the Pinus Pinea; received from the Mediterranean— We got home as night was closing in—
17. IV:15. Sunday.

Visited my Nursery this morning and took a note of the trees now in it— Of which there are of old that is existing, before the ground was set off for planting 3. Appletrees, one withSuckers and one central separate Sucker—2 Wild Cherries, young from old Stumps—1. Elder 1 ElmSweet briar Rose bushesBlackberry Vines 1. Thimbleberry Vine, and one hop-vine creeping over from Mr Beale’s ground— Of my plantations 36 Apple-trees 5. Apricots. 2. Mazzard Cherries 28. Horse-ChesnutsElms. 3. Oaks from AcornsEnglish Oaks set out 16. Peaches. 1. Pear. 2 Plums, and 1. Button planted by Charles. I take this note now to mark how many of the young trees will be killed by the ensuing Winter’s frosts, and how many by the next Summer’s Suns.— Mr George Whitney preached for his father—from Romans 12.11 in the Morning, “Not slothful in business[”]—a very earnest discourse upon the virtue of Industry—and in the afternoon from Acts 11.35. But in every Nation, he that feareth God, and worketh righteousness is accepted with him— The subjects of both these Sermons were topics of plain morality, and the discourses were written in a fervid Spirit, becoming the youth of the preacher— Industry is not one of the Virtues peculiar to the Christian System— It belongs to every School of Morals; though perhaps it has been more emphatically recommended by Solomon than by any other Ethical writer— Industry is a virtue liable to excess; and Jesus in his rebuke to Martha, and in his instruction to take no thought of the Morrow, taught his disciples the merit of moderation even in the exercise of good and active energies— The maxim and its limitation were both among the sayings of the Wise Men of Greece— One said that the Gods yielded all things to Industry— The devise of the other was “not too much”— Mr Whitney dwelt altogether upon the Rule, and scarcely seemed aware of the existence of exceptions— There was no occasion for such qualification to the doctrine of the afternoon, which was upon the universal efficacy of piety and righteousness to obtain acceptance with God. Mr George Whitney is himself commendably industrious, and is reaping the certain reward of that quality in his own improvement— He has a good voice, and reads well— He thinks too; and delivers the thoughts of his own mind, and not common place repetition— His Style is ambitious and ornamented, but unequal mingling phrases of coarse homespun,—with interwoven lace and embroidery. This is a corrigible fault which time and study will reform. Louisa C. Smith—Elizabeth C. Adams dined with us, and Joseph Harrod Adams— Isaac Hull with Joseph had breakfasted here, on his way from Boston— Elizabeth was engaged after Meeting with a Class of the Sunday School; and did not return here this Evening— I spent part of it at Mr Thomas Greenleaf’s— Daniel Greenleaf was also there. T. Greenleaf promised to ask his Son Price to call upon me and advise me, with regard to the trimming and management of my young Trees.
18. V. Monday

Lewis Bass called on me again this morning with a proposal to sell to me the lot of Land which is nearly interlocked with mine upon the opposite Hill. He supposes there is about 24 Acres of it, and his price is 100 dollars an Acre— I thought this too much, but proposed to go with him at an early day, and
look over the ground. In the Nursery, I completed the Trench W. of the Alley, and planted Juglans Porcina Amara, Chesnuts, White Oak Acorns, Pear and Office Apple Seeds; and scattered Wild Cherries— A Sickel Pear Core in Book-Box N. 2. with Stake and Stone— I was called away by Deacon Spear and his brother William to visit the Woodlots near the Railway, upon which I propose to make a Sale of Wood— I followed them, but did not find them; they and I being driven home by a Northeast Gale and Storm of rain, which came on, and continued the whole day; much to my disappointment— I found two Black Oak Acorns at the Sturdy Oak beyond Mrs Baxter’s; which I brought home with intent to plant. Elizabeth C. Adams came this morning—and my wife returned before dinner from her visit to Boston— Received Letters from Judge Story, and N. Dane, with the printed Appendix to Mr Dane’s Abridgment of American Law. This morning I finished reading the fragments of Cicero’s Books de Republica as last published by Angelo May.— There were already extant considerable fragments of these Books—extracts preserved by Seneca, Macrobius, Nonius, Fronto, Lactantius, St. Augustine and others—and particularly the Somnium Scipionis from the sixth book. The part now discovered contains perhaps one third of the first book; one fourth of the second—as much of the third; but none or next to none of the fourth, fifth and sixth— The parts now recovered are authenticated by their own excellence; and altogether equals any other part of the writings of Cicero— Scipio lays it down that neither of the three simple forms of Government is good: that a composition of the three is the best form of Government; but finally pronounces the Roman Republic itself the most perfect of Governments; illustrating his Sentiments by historical references to the most important institutions, and to the Events which gave rise to them— An elaborate vindication of Justice, as essential and indispensable to good Government is the principal part assigned in the Dialogue to Laelius, but is unfortunately not among the recovered portions. This was no doubt introduced in imitation of the Republic of Plato— Every friend to virtue who reads these broken sentences of a great mind, will yet long for the discovery of the parts still lost— It is apparent that the main argument of the work is the same with that of my fathers Defence of the American Constitutions, and even the few pages now restored to light contain authorities sanctioning his principles as high and venerable as any of these which he was enabled to adduce.
19. V. Tuesday.

Deacon Spear called here this morning, and told me that he had yesterday inspected the Woodlots where he thought it would be advisable for me to sell this year the standing wood— He proposes to go next Friday Morning and lay it out in lots for Sale; and I told him that I would go with him— I was in the Nursery till Noon; digging out from my Stony-barren centre a number of Stones, weighing from one to two hundred pounds each; for which I was obliged to call my aid Salmon Farrar and the Crow-bar— Filled the vacated spaces with mould from the garden, mingled with the little Soil at the Stony-barren itself— I continued planting the trench from the central Apple-tree to the central Rock under the western Wall— Planted a second row—Juglans promiscuus Chesnuts, Acorns, Apple-seeds, Wild Cherries and Pear Cores— The ground of this range under that Western Wall, I apprehend is not sufficiently broken up— Planted sturdy Black Oak Acorns in Book-box N 1. and Trask Pear Seeds in Book-box N. 3 each with Stake and Stone— After dinner I called at Elisha Turner’s the Taylor, and then at Deacon Josiah Adams’s— He went with me, and shewed me where were the old boundaries of the Babcock lot in the Penn’s Valley farm; and gave me some advice with regard to the leasing of the lots, of Penn’s Valley— There are on the Babcock lot, perhaps two hundred Oaks—Scrubs, grown up from the Roots of old trees formerly there but now cut
down— None of them four feet high—on one of them were a few good Acorns which I gathered to plant— I found also a handful of sound Black Oak Acorns just fallen from a tree in the Druid Pasture— I agreed with Mr Adams to drain some low land adjoining his, and which needs some joint ditching. Elizabeth C. Adams went home this Evening. Alpheus Spear came and settled his Rent for two Quarters to the last of September, for which he gave me his Note payable 1. January next with interest; deducting his bill for work and repairs on the farm. I spoke to him about breaking up the ground for my Orchard with a border of Oaks— He said it should be ready for planting the acorns next Saturday; and advised me to plant with the Acorns some Shagbarks and some Chesnuts, which I determined to do— Received an invitation from the Soul of Soldiery, a Militia Company in Boston, to dine with them upon their anniversary on the 25th. which I answered, declining.— Received also a Note from Charles which I answered— Began reading in Ernesti’s Edition of Cicero, the Consolatio, purporting to be the book of which he wrote for his own consolation, upon the death of his daughter Tullia— Of questionable authenticity.
20 V. Wednesday.

Lewis Bass came this morning and I walked with him over the hill, and viewed his lot of ground, which he has offered to sell me. He has been advised since he saw me before by John Bass not to sell the whole, but to reserve the part which borders on the road— There are about 15 Acres of what he now offers for sale; which would be a very convenient addition to my farm; and which contain all that would be peculiarly valuable for such addition— The land bordering upon the road is however much better in soil and in situation. I told Mr Bass I would enquire to what use I could turn it, if I should make the purchase, and then make him an offer for it— Returning home I gathered a quantity of round bitter pignuts which are falling ripe from the trees— From Brieslers J. Kirke brought me of Shagbarks, English Walnuts, and Chesnuts for trial— Not one of the English Walnuts sinks in Water— This Nut is said to be exceedingly difficult to raise in this Country— I planted this morning a Cross Trench at the Stony-barren West of the Alley two rows, with a Stake of 12 Druid Black Oak Acorns— Then Chesnuts, mingled Juglans, Apple-Seeds, Pear Cores; Stranger berries, wild cherries and grape seeds. Began to dig in another cross-Trench, but found the Spade arrested by several large Stones, when I was called away. This afternoon Mr Price Greenleaf called on me, and visited my Nursery. I wanted his advice for the management of my young trees from the seed and Stone—of which I have about seventy, needing skilful care to save their lives and aid their growth— Most if not all Peach trees have the fatal white worms near the root—and we found one of them, mining the thriftiest of my Apricots—A tree which it seldom attacks— Mr Greenleaf says that fruit-trees may be pruned at any time; but that they should be transplanted only after the fall of their leaves— This morning was fair, but in the afternoon there blew up a short and heavy gale, with a South or South west wind, and much rain. It confined me to the house— Read some pages of W. Tudor’s Journal of his last Voyage to South-America. And I answered a Letter received from H. W. Boxley of Baltimore; with a biographical sketch of the late Coll. Peter Little— My wife determined not to go to Washington this Winter.
21. V. Thursday—

Three hours this morning in the Nursery. Planted two Cross Trenches in double rows, E of the Alley—Druid Babcock Acorns with a Stake and Stone— With them English Walnuts—Shagbarks, Chesnuts, Apple seeds—Pear-Cores—Stranger-berries. As these are on the Stony-barren
region, I resolved to draw out the large Stones growing near the surface of the ground, and to supply their places with black mould from the garden. I called for Salmon Farrar with his Crow-bar, and took out ten or twelve Stones weighing each from forty to two hundred pounds— Smaller Stones in proportion. The largest of all was partly under the roots of a thrifty young Apricot, and of a young Horse Chesnut—both of which were shaken, and almost uprooted by its removal— After dinner, I walked to the Mount Wollaston farm, and saw the men, ploughing up the ground for the Orchard with the border of Oaks, Shagbarks, and Chesnuts which I propose to plant— There are fifteen furrows at the distances of two rods, and parallel to each other; besides the border for the forest trees— Alpheus Spear went to the Cattle Show at Brighton yesterday and had not returned— My next trip was across the fields to the Stonyfield hill as my father sometime called it— I measured by pacing, the line across from corner to corner through Lewis Bass’s Land, scooping in upon mine— On Withington’s plan, it must be about 42 Rods, and on pacing it, I made it between 120 and 125 paces; which is nearly as accurate as the chain could make it— I gathered half a bag full of bitter pignuts, fallen from the trees. John Kirke was sent to Boston this afternoon to bespeak a passage for Articles to be sent to Washington for my Son John’s wife and family— He brought me some Shagbarks and Chesnuts for planting.
22. V. Friday.

Nursery— Planted 2. Cross Rows W. and one East of the Alley—one Juglans amara in the Drupe, and one of the same sort of Nut naked—with Chesnuts promiscuous Acorns—Apple Seeds, Pear Cores, stranger berries and scattered wild Cherries— Mistaking the arrangement which I had made with Deacon Spear, for this morning, I went with S. Farrar this Morning to the Field wood-lot at the Railway, where I expected to meet him, to lay out the lots of standing wood to be sold— Not finding him there I returned, and soon after, Deacon Spear and Harvey Field called upon me— They had been at Penn’s Valley farm, expecting me there; for the distribution of the lots of Land to be there leased at Auction, next Wednesday. Upon conversation with them, I fixed upon the distinct lots to be set up, of which I afterwards made a minute in writing. My brother dined with us. I passed the afternoon and Evening at home, and finished reading the Consolatio— This long treatise of 65 pages in Ernesti’s Edition, purporting to have been written by Cicero for his own Consolation, upon the death of his daughter Tullia.— That he did write such a Treatise is certain, from notices of it in several other of his works— Middleton merely says this this has been long acknowledged by the learned to be spurious— The earliest edition of Cicero that I possess is in one Quarto Volume printed at Geneva 1632. with commentary and Notes of Lambinus and of Dionysius Gothofredus. In this Edition the Consolatio is included as the work of Cicero; but in a marginal Note the editor declares it in his opinion to be spurious, because Cicero himself in the second Tusculan, and in the second book de divinatione declares that in his Consolatio, he had collected accounts of the disastrous deaths of the most illustrious Citizens of Rome; scarcely any of which are mentioned in this book.— In the Elzevir Edition by Schrevelius 1661. The Consolatio is printed as of Cicero, si Deo placet—if it please god—and it is precisely so, a century later in the Edition of Ernesti— In D’Olivet’s Edition, as I have it printed at Padua 1753. it is not all included; nor as I can perceive at all noticed— Though he gives two or three short fragments from the genuine book de Consolatione, and an extract from Sigonius, an Epitome of what he supposed the genuine Treatise to contain, agreeing very much with this apocryphal book. The reason assigned in the Edition of Denys Godefroy, for rejecting the Consolatio as it is, has not much weight,
for there are chasms of lost passages in it; and there are statements of tragical deaths of distinguished Romans— The inferiority of the composition to that of the other works of Cicero is a better evidence of its illegitimacy, and yet it is very well written; by no mean imitator of the Master’s hand— The strongest market of the counterfeit is its coldness— There is none of the pungency of grief under which he says he wrote this Treatise— A feeble and bloodless eulogium upon Tullia, scarcely occupies half a page, and there is not a manifestation of acute feeling in the whole work— How I crept in among the writings of Cicero, it would absorb too much time at present to enquire.
23. IV. Saturday.

John Kirke went to Boston this morning, and took with him Trunks and boxes of effects of my Son John’s wife, who is shortly to return to Washington— They were shipped on board of the Seceder, a Schooner, Captain Churchill— I spent the day, (with the exception of about an hour when I returned home, and dined,) upon Mount Wollaston, upon the Southeastern declivity of which I commenced my experiment upon a larger Scale of raising forest trees from the seed— I had laid out a lot nearly square from the road, and containing about five Acres, for an Apple Orchard—and as it was to be fenced in I resolved to raise this border of forest trees round the Orchard— One Rod wide of the ground, has accordingly been ploughed up in furrows and harrowed, all round the Square— Three sides of it were planted this day, in five rows to each side, with Acorns, Chesnuts, and Shagbarks— They were planted in hills about 3 feet apart; one row on the Northern edge of the lot, and where the fence is to stand with an acorn, a Shagbark and a Chesnut upon each hill. On all the rest, the two Nuts or an Acorn and a nut to each Hill.— The Acorns, are those which I have been able to gather within the last Month— Those which Charles brought from Weston, and those which Spear’s boys could pick up under the groves of the farm— The Shagbarks and Chesnuts were purchased at Brigham’s and Briesler’s and at Boston Market— There were about a peck of each, and on each side were planted, about 1800 nuts or acorns 1/3 of each “Quod felix faustumque sit.” Our farmer’s are so much the creatures of habit; and so totally unused to raise forest trees from the nut, or indeed from any kind of planting, that this attempt is almost universally considered as a wild and foolish expense and waste of Land— Briesler told me to day when I was purchasing Shagbarks, to plant, and rejecting all that floated upon water, that I was doing one good thing at the old farm; in setting out an Orchard—leaving me to understand that he thought the other part of my Scheme, a vagary— So my forest, will only pass under the shelter of my Orchard; as Moliere to draw an Audience to his Misanthrope was obliged to couple it with Medecin Malgré lui— One of Spear’s men who was planting with us, said that it would be a Months work next Spring and Summer to hoe these hills— I ask no better than that it may be—for it implies that a large portion of the trees will come up. We finished the third side about five this afternoon—leaving the fourth, for another day— Returning home I called, and passed an hour at my brother’s.

24. IV 30. Heard Mr Gannett of Cambridge port, in the morning from Psalm 107.8. “Oh that men would praise the Lord for his Goodness, and for his wonderful works to the children of men!”—and in the afternoon, from Matthew 7.20. “Wherefore by their fruits ye shall know them.” Mr Gannett’s discourses are very well written and read with great propriety— They are elegant compositions, delivered with much solemnity of manner, and abound with good reason and good feeling— All this is common to the Sermons of many young men recently educated at Cambridge— Their great deficiency is of vivacity— This applies both to the writing and the delivery— There is excellent doctrine—choice language, and nothing to remember— I incline to make my Memory the standard of merit for Sermons. I admire in proportion as I remember them— Louisa C. Smith dined with us— I read the fragments of Cicero’s Poetry, and with them completed the perusal of everything written by him, now known to be extant— It has occupied an average of two hours a day for ten Months—and has left me with a desire to spend at least as much more time, in studying here more profoundly.— Whether this opportunity will be indulged me, is doubtful— I am now precisely at the age when the life of Cicero, was so tragically closed, and the time which can remain for me in this life should be otherwise spent than in Studies which should have been completed thirty years since— Lessons of wisdom can henceforth be of little avail for practical use to me. Lessons of Language, Rhetoric and Logic are still less susceptible of being turned to profitable account— But the taste for Classical Literature, formed in youth, adheres to one in age, when it can no longer be of much benefit— The principal Poetry of Cicero now extant, is a translation in Latin Hexameters of Greek Poem of Aratus upon Astronomy, called phenomena— The Original of Aratus is also extant, and the work of Cicero being mutilated Grotius undertook to supply the deficient parts— I read this Morning in Ernesti’s Edition, containing only the verses of Cicero; about 400 lines. The versification is not to be compared with that of Virgil or of Ovid— Perhaps not even with that of Lucretius. There was a sevret of harmony in Latin versification, which Cicero, though a perfect master of all the possibilities of harmony in Latin prose, did not discover— The poem of Aratus is a description of the Celestial Constellations— Less lively and poetical than the Astronomics of Manilius. The translation by Cicero was a youthful exercise; but he gives an extract from it of near 100 lines in his Books de Natura Deorum— There are a few lines, upon his own Consulate; and the two so ridiculed by Quinctilian and Juvenal—One of them—Cedant Arma Togae, concedat Laurea Linguae, he acknowledges and defends—the other was probably never written by him— It does not appear to have been quoted against him by Antony, though far more open to his scoffing commentary— It is remarkable that in all the fragments preserved there is not one other censurable line.
25. IV:30. Monday.

Saw Arcturus rise about half past four in the same Quarter with The Stars of the Bull— George Veasey the Carpenter was here this morning, and has made an estimate of the cost of repairing my house which he says will amount to 340 dollars exclusive of the painting— I desired him to commence upon the work immediately and he said he would come on Thursday. Deacon Spear followed— I had drawn up a notice for the Auction on Wednesday, for the leasing of my Penn’s Valley houses and farm—which upon Conversation with him I varied
so much that I was obliged to write it over again. This mode of leasing that farm was attempted more than twenty years ago and failed— I expect it will fail again; but I must try all lawful expedients to dispose of it— The Executors Sale of the Woodlots is to be in the afternoon— Deacon Spear took with him the two plans of them, to be shewn at the Sale. A man named John Jones went by with the remnant of a Waggon load of Chesnuts from New-Hampshire, which I took; chiefly to plant— He sent for me into the Nursery for curiosity of seeing me—which he repeated he valued much more than the selling of his Chesnuts— He said he had lived with my father and worked upon this farm more than twenty years ago. He told me too that notwithstanding his plain dress he was not a poor man—he was worth five thousand dollars, and had influence; and had used it, in favour of me— Mr Humphrey the Surveyor brought me the plan of the Mount Wollaston farm; but I found he had not laid down the Mount upon it— He took it back for that purpose— I went with him to the Mount— On the road the lengths of rail fence from the first fence West of the House to the second, are 15 lengths to the gate and 35 including the gate to the Westernmost fence.— Northward 85 lengths to the Angle then 60 to opposite the cedar tree on the North-eastern declivity—18 paces or 6 rods from the fence to the Cedar—and 86 lengths from the cedar to the Creek. I desired Mr Humphrey to lay down the ridge of the Mount—the fence across from the Creek to the road, and the solitary Cedar tree, which he promised— Mrs Miller, Abigail S. Adams, and Caroline Harrod visited our Ladies. After dinner I went to Braintree in search of Acorns and Wild Pears, and found none—but brought home some Atherton Crab Apples for seed. They are sour almost as lemon juice but the seed are sound— In my theory seed from a rugged Stock, or from hard soil, or a bleak aspect removed to kinder soil and nurture will improve— I called at Mr Capen’s to enquire for young Apple-trees, but he was gone to Brighton— Then at Deacon Adams’s; he was gone to Boston. I read this morning part of Ernesti’s Dedication of his Edition of Cicero to Stiglitz— An admirable defence of classical Literature, and of the Study of the Greek and Latin writers, and especially of Cicero— I was but a short time in the Nursery— Opened in part only two or three short furrows West of the Alley.
26. V:30. Tuesday.

Morning in the Nursery— Salmon Farrar employed with the Crowbar, digging up large Stones from the Stony-barren— I finished the furrow from the central Apple-tree to the central Rock. Filled it with New Hampshire Chesnuts—Shagbarks—Floating Acorns and Atherton Crab Apple Seeds Planted two cross furrows, East of the Alley: Atherton Crabs and New-Hampshire Chesnuts, mixed with Acorns, Shagbarks, Plum stones and scattered wild Cherries— This afternoon I went to Deacon Adams’s. He will attend the Auction Sales to-morrow— I called also at Brigham’s shop; to make some enquiries about the state and prospects of the Quincy Canal. The Stone Cutters have emigrated in a body to Sandy-Bay, so that there is scarcely any transportation of Stone, upon the Canal at-all— The proceeds of the Canal have therefore fallen this year, to less than half what they were the last and preceding year; and my speculations in this property have been failures. Deacon Spear was at my house this Evening; and I gave him the final paper of directions, for the Sale of my Leases to-morrow— This morning, my son John’s wife received a Letter from him requesting her to leave this to-morrow, and meet him at New-York, on Friday Morning. She determined therefore to go— He did not know his mother’s determination not to go this winter to Washington, and advised that his eldest child, Louisa, should
remain here, with Mrs Nowlan, to go on afterwards with us— But both the Children and Mrs Nowland are to go— The arrangement is that they are to go with the barouche and pair of small horses, which John is to take on to Washington and to sell there. John Kirke, and his wife are to go on with them to New-York, and then return here— I propose to go with them as far as Providence.
27. V. Wednesday— From Quincy to Walpole.

Sent Mary’s large trunk, by Gillet of the Quincy Stage, with a Note to Charles, asking him to send on the Trunk by the Stage to Providence to-morrow— At eleven my Son John’s wife, with her two infant daughters, John Kirke and his wife, left Quincy, in the Barouche; with the ponies— I gave Mary a Letter for her husband, and with Salmon Farrar, the Chaise and one of the large horses, accompanied them on their first days Journey. We dined at Bride’s at Dedham; and reached Fuller’s Tavern at Walpole, just before four O’Clock— The weather was fair and moderate— I had intended to go with them as far as Providence; but finding that Mary and both the Children bore the Journey this day perfectly well— I concluded if the weather should be fair in the Morning, to proceed no farther but return to Quincy— At Bride’s I saw a Boston Patriot Newspaper, with the proceedings of the Norfolk County Convention of National Republicans on Monday— They nominated Genl. H. A. S. Dearborn, as a Candidate to represent the District in the 22d. Congress; and passed Resolutions one of which was in honour of Mr Clay. But an old man at Bride’s, the same who accosted me there when I passed through in June, told me that the Anti-masonic Convention had met yesterday and nominated Mr French now a member of the Senate of the Commonwealth— I attempted to both read and write this Evening at Walpole, with little success— I read a few pages of Mr Dane’s Appendix. He shews very forcibly that under our System, no State Legislature possess the power to nullify an Act of Congress: there are two or three indirect allusions to the Hartford Convention, of which Dane was a member, and to its doctrines—with a consciousness of the error of their proceedings; an effort to be understood as denying that they had any designs hostile to the Union; and a decently veiled admission that they were standing upon untenable ground, and acting under their influence of factious motives— This morning I finished reading the Dedication by Ernesti of his Cicero to Stiglitz. I had read it once before with Admiration. Of all the Editors and Commentators of the Greek and Latin Classics, I should pronounce Ernesti the first.
28. V. Thursday— Return from Walpole to Quincy.

At a quarter past seven this morning, my daughter with her two children, Mrs Nowlan, John Kirke and his wife left Fuller’s house at Walpole proceeding to Providence, there to embark in the Steamboat for New-York, at Noon— A few minutes after I left the same house with Salmon Farrar, in the Chaise and returned to Quincy— Stopping half an hour at Bride’s at Dedham to rest the horse I reached home between 11. O’Clock and Noon. Deacon Spear soon afterwards came in. Both his Auction Sales were made yesterday— Neither of the houses was leased; and only three or four of the lots of Land; but this disappointment was not unexpected. The two lots of Woodland, at the Executors Sale were struck off to me at 23 dollars an Acre— I agreed to go with Deacon Spear to morrow, when he is to stake off in woodlots the land upon which the standing wood is to be sold. Elizabeth C. Adams dined with us— Her brother Joseph H came
came for her in the Evening— Degrand came out from Boston and spent the Evening with me— Brought some European news— John Randolph’s eccentricities at St. Petersburg. The accidental and lamentable death of Mr Huskisson, at the opening of the Liverpool Manchester Rail-way— The symptoms of troublous times on the European Continent; and idle Speculations upon our Political Affairs— Degrand is a broker, and says that the opinion that it will be perfectly proper for me to go to Congress if elected, is gaining ground, two per cent a week.
29. IV. Friday—

Wrote this morning to my Son John— My brother called at 8 O’Clock, and we went to the Woodlots upon which the wood is to be sold, standing; called the Field, Joy and Savil lots— I took the plans with me; but even with them obtained very imperfectly the idea of their bounds. The rail-way crosses them all three— I found at the ground Deacon Spear with his brother William, and two other men; who were staking off the lots for Sale— Mr James Hall went round with us, and knowing all the bounds, pointed them out— Some of them have been removed by the workmen upon the Rail-way— We entered at Mr Hall’s gate, and proceeded to the Field lot, through his Land upon which it borders— We met Deacon Adams upon the ground Hall conducted us to several of the corner bounds; which are remarkable for being upon large and high Rocks— We went to the Railway tower immediately South of which part of my Land extends— S. Farrar; by my direction took up five Roots of wild Strawberry vines, which I found there growing out of the Rocks; and which immediately on returning home I had set out at the Northwest corner of my Garden— I fear too late in the Season— I found at home Mrs Dexter and her daughter Mrs M’Kay, visiting Mrs Adams— My brother dined with us— I endeavoured to read and to and to write after dinner, but was overpowered by weariness, and obliged to desist. I began this morning to read the Preface of Ernesti to his Clavis, but could not finish it.
30. IV:30. Saturday.— Sun rose

I sent Salmon Farrar this morning with the Chaise to Dedham, expecting that Kirke and his wife would return from New-York, and come from Providence in the Stage—but they did not come, and Farrar returned this Evening alone. Mr. Capen was here, and told me that he had a number of grafted young Apple trees for sale; which I promised to come and see next Wednesday— He also mentioned the four Acres of fresh meadow which he had bidden off at the Sale of my Leases, and about which he appears to have understood that the adjoining pasture was to be included in the Lease— Louisa C. Smith called to see Mrs Adams. In the Nursery, I planted 3. Shagbarks from Mr Brooks’s trees at Medford, which Charles’s wife sent me— Also 3 whole Office Apples—Chesnuts—Juglans Porcina Amara—Atherton Crab and other Apple-seeds—Acorns. 3. Plum stones—3. English walnuts; and scattered wild cherries. All in the broken furrows between the young trees West of the alley— Opened four Cross furrows East of the Alley— After dinner I walked over the hills to the Druid Plains, where I found a remnant of white Oak-Acorns under three trees— One of them where I had found none before— The tap-roots of almost all the Acorns that were alive had taken hold of the ground, where some of them had penetrated from three to four inches deep. The leaves of the Oaks have almost entirely fallen, and the trees are strip’d as in Mid winter— Among the walnuts there are three distinct varieties of the Pignut— One round without a regular appearance. thin shelled, and with a bitter kernel: of this class are the whole row on the Trask Hill—
One smaller—round—thick and hard shelled, and upon cracking which the kernel falls to pieces—and one, which approaches to the Shagbark; with angular protuberances slightly marked, and a hard, flattened shell, and a kernel, sweet as the Shagbarks itself, but not cracking into halves— Of these two kinds are the rows in the square Druid Pasture— The trees which thus stand in rows, are self-planted, and producing all the same kind of Nut seem to prove that the tree follows the nature of the nut. Other varieties in the foliage or vegetation of the trees I have not remarked. The wood of the pignut appears to be harder than that of the Shagbark. This morning I finished reading the Prefaces to the two first Editions of Ernesti’s Clavis— In which he gives an exposition of his reasons, for reducing his commentary upon Cicero to this form: and they are conclusive— The work consists of five Indexes. 1. of Laws. 2. Geographical— 3. Historical, chiefly an account of persons, mentioned by Cicero— 4. Of Latin words, including only such as are not found, or are ill explained in the Dictionaries. 5. Graeco-Latin—an explanation of the Greek words which abound in Cicero’s writings—particularly in the Letters to Atticus— And as they are generally quotations from the Poets this Index gives notice whence they are taken, and as much of the passage cited as serves to shew how it is applicable in the quotation— In this Preface Ernesti recommends with warm approbation Burmann’s preface to his Edition of Phaedrus, and he concurs in the advice of Lipsius whom he mentions as observing that whoever would profitably study Cicero, must devote two years to reading and again reading him without the intermission of a day— In this opinion I fully concur— I received this morning a Letter from General La Fayette, of 8. September last, enclosing several printed documents relating to his share in the recent Revolution in France.
31. IV:15. Sunday.

Heard Mr Dean of Scituate in the morning from Mark 2:29. “And he said unto them, The sabbath was made for man, and not man for the Sabbath[”]; and in the afternoon from Acts 3.19. “Be converted” both ingenious and eloquent Sermons. There is a peculiarity in Mr Dean’s mode of delivery, which most of the auditors here, dislike— It is inconceivable, how many modes there are of bad speaking, and how exceedingly rare it is to hear a good Speaker in the pulpit. Mr Dean’s fault is not the cold inanimate manner so common among the preacher’s of this neighbourhood; but a form of vivacity which passes for affectation, and which is thought to partake of levity— In the morning Sermon he gave a historical account of the Institution of the Sabbath; of the reasons assigned for it in the old Testament— Of its adaptation to the new Covenant; as a commemoration of the Resurrection of Jesus Christ; and of the change by the Apostles of the day upon which it is solemnized, from the seventh to the first day of the week— At the close of the Discourse he animadverted with severity upon the attempts now making to divide the Parish and set up a new Religious Society of Universalists— This project has been several years fermenting, and will now undoubtedly succeed— Great numbers of the congregational Churches are breaking up by Sectarian Secessions— Some from and some to Calvinism—Baptistism—Methodism, Unitarianism, and Universalism— The Church at Quincy had been peculiarly fortunate in its harmony— As the population of the town increased the Meeting House became too small for the number of worshippers— It overflowed partly into the Episcopal Church where a
respectable and very popular clergyman by the name of Cutler was settled; moderately Calvinistic and Trinitarian— But Mr Cutler within the last two years has pulmonary complaints which obliged him to pass the last Winter in Georgia, and will make a Southern climate necessary to him for the next— He will probably never return to Quincy, where his place is now temporarily supplied by a Mr Potter— Last year a new Meeting House was built at the Railway in Milton but on the borders of Quincy; and has taken away some of Mr Whitney’s Parishioners— Meantime the Universalist Preachers have been making gradual approaches, and for some months past have held meetings on Sunday Evenings at the Town Hall— This day they have advanced a step further and had public worship, morning, afternoon and Evening— The wolf is thus in Mr Whitney’s fold; and the Spirit of dissension is spreading over his flock, under the auspices of Universal Salvation— Mr Dean pointed out the consequences, but reason against Sectarianism, is oil to a flame— His Sermon of the afternoon upon the text Be converted, was equally sound and rational Anti-Calvinism— But there is so little of that species of Bigotry in Quincy that there was no need of preaching against it. Louisa C. Smith dined with us— She is going to-morrow, for the Winter to Boston— S. Farrar went to Dedham for John Kirke and his wife; and returned without them; but they came soon after. Mary and her family arrived safely at New-York on Friday afternoon at five O’Clock— My Son John was there to meet them—

Day. My course of life is undergoing a change; my family being suddenly and greatly reduced. I rise between four and five in the Morning— Make my fire— Read three chapter in the Bible, and four or six pages of the fragments illustrative of Scripture—a Supplement to the English Translation of Calmet’s Dictionary. Also portions of Cicero, and Comments upon his works— Began this Morning the version of Aratus’s Poem, subjoined to Pingré’s Translation of the Astronomics of Manilius— Since the departure of Mrs Nowlan my time for breakfast is about nine— I then pass from two to three hours digging and planting in the Nursery—but that must be very soon given up for the winter— From noon till two this Diary gives me employment; and that or Letter-writing after dinner and in the Evening— The fine autumnal weather invites me out to walk over the Hills, in search of Nuts and Acorn’s— Between nine and ten is time for bed. I find it almost impracticable to read or write in the Evening.
